awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Toward an Improved Understanding of the Sinks and Photochemical Sources of Nitrous Acid on Boundary Layer Surfaces
awd_abstract_narration:
This research is focused on the investigation of selected urban and soil surfaces for their potential to serve as sources and/or sinks of nitrous acid to/from the atmosphere. Nitrous acid is an especially important compound in atmospheric chemistry because of its ability to serve as a precursor to the formation of the hydroxyl radical and thereby influence the oxidizing capacity of the atmosphere. Current chemical models are unable to reproduce the observed profiles of atmospheric nitrous acid, due in part to the fact that its sources and sinks are not well understood. Recent studies suggest that significant daytime production of nitrous acid may be attributed to heterogeneous reactions on various environmental surfaces, such as asphalt, cement, and soils. 

Laboratory studies will be conducted to generate the kinetics and photochemical data needed to advance predictive models of ambient nitrous acid (HONO) levels. This research will determine the reaction probabilities for (a) the uptake of HONO on soil, asphalt, and cement; and (b) nitrogen dioxide (NO2) conversion to HONO on iron oxides and asphalt under atmospheric conditions. Measured uptake coefficients will help to constrain the fraction of HONO that may be loss to boundary layer surfaces. The quantum yields of HONO formation and molar absorptivity values measured for nitrate adsorbed to surfaces (such as soil) are key parameters that will enable calculations of HONO fluxes from these sources.

por.por_cntn:
An understanding of atmospheric processes is essential to provide policymakers with accurate information they need to address rapid anthropogenic alteration of Earth’s atmosphere in a timely and cost-effective manner. Most policy decisions are based on predictive atmospheric models that have become necessarily complex as they have been extended to answer global-scale questions. Unfortunately current models are unable to accurately represent all of the important chemical processes since only a limited number of chemical reactions are well-characterized. This is especially true for reactions involving the gas nitrous acid. Nitrous acid is an important reactive gas in the lower atmosphere that controls how long air pollutants exist in air and promotes processes that lead to smog events. Unfortunately, despite decades of research, we still don’t know where nitrous acid comes from. The overall objective of this NSF award was to provide a more accurate understanding of how nitrous acid is formed in the lower atmosphere. 

Intellectual Merit: The research carried out with support of this NSF award provided the following knowledge: (1) We showed that nitrous acid is formed on soil and airborne dust particles through the interaction of gases such as nitrogen dioxide with iron-containing minerals and organic matter; (2) we found that nitrate, a common pollutant of water and soil, degrades in sunlight to release large amounts of nitrous acid and that the mechanism for this release depends on the presence of organic matter in soil and airborn dust; (3) when nitrate present in polluted sea salt is exposed to sunlight, it degrades to chlorine containing gases that escape into the atmosphere where they can play a role in air pollution events; (4) we discovered new mechanisms involving reactive free radicals and previously unrecognized surface phenomena that lead to nitrous acid formation on soil surfaces; and (5) we discovered that bacteria naturally present in soil convert nitrogen fertilizers into nitrous acid and related nitrogen oxide gases and that these gases can impact local air quality. The scientific community will benefit from this research since insights gained on the chemical mechanisms driving nitrous acid formation will be important for understanding chemistry occurring in snowpack, clouds, and mineral dust, which are other active areas of research in the field of atmospheric chemistry.

Broader Impacts:  The research made possible with this award filled important knowledge gaps in our understanding of where nitrous acid comes from. In doing so, scientists who model atmospheric composition are better able to describe nitrogen cycling in the atmosphere and its impacts on study air pollution and global climate change. As such, environmental policy based on predictive atmospheric models will based on more accurate data. Besides contributing knowledge, this award supported the training of numerous graduate and undergraduate students, effectively training them for STEM careers. Their work has been disseminated in theses, peer-reviewed journal articles, and presented at national meetings. In addition, students and the principal investigator worked with Indiana University programs and K-12 teachers to inspire students to pursue STEM degrees and enrich science curricula at local schools. This includes: (1) Mentoring undergraduate students during a summer from the Groups Scholars Program at Indiana University, an initiative to increase college attendance among first-generation, underrepresented students; (2) establishing an ozone monitoring system at local school that allowed students to monitor air pollution data in real time; (3) creating project-based learning modules based on air pollution data for high school science classes; (4) providing chemical-demonstrations and lecture material to K-12 classes; and (5) participating in annual science open-house events at Indiana University.
